WestPalmBeach.com Visitors Guide to West Palm Beach, FL Home Calendar Concert Tickets Hotels & Resorts Attractions Activities Fishing Golf History Jobs Real Estate Restaurants Shops Clematis CityPlace Weather Contact Ticket Support CityPlace CityPlace Business Directory CityPlace (Rosemary Square) is comprised of 600,000 square feet of retail businesses, over 20 restaurants, a 20-screen theater, open-air plaza, cultural arts theater as well as hundreds of private residences. Come shop in a place where old-world architecture, beautiful fountains, and sidewalk cafes create an atmosphere strikingly reminiscent of a European town center. The Kravis Center for the Performing Arts borders the west side of CityPlace and walking north on Rosemary Avenue will take you straight into the Historic Clematis Street area. Below is our Business directory. Click here for a map of CityPlace. Take the FREE Molly’s Trolley with pick-ups every 10-15 minutes throughout downtown West Palm Beach! Note to businesses: You may add, delete or amend your business listing by contacting WestPalmBeach.com here . This Place Is Who We Are : Stories of Indigenous Leadership, Resilienc
    
    
    
      – Harbour Publishing Skip to content Facebook Instagram Account Shopping Cart Home About Books More Harbour Publishing More Browse All New Bestsellers Forthcoming Award Winning Books Read Local! Children's Books Teen and Young Adult Print on Demand Books Nightwood Editions More Browse All Award Winning Books Children's Books Crosswords and Puzzles Fiction Forthcoming Memoir and Biography Nature Poetry Short Stories Sports Raincoast Chronicles More Browse All Authors News Events Contact Submissions Facebook Instagram Sign In Shopping Cart This Place Is Who We Are: Stories of Indigenous Leadership, Resilience, and Connection to Homelands Katherine Palmer Gordon Foreword by: Dallas Smith $39.95 Product Form Paperback / softback Paperback / softback Quantity Add to Cart This item is a recurring or deferred purchase. By continuing, I agree to the cancellation policy and authorize you to charge my payment method at the prices, frequency and dates listed on this page until my order is fulfilled or I cancel, if permitted. Find an eBook on: Find a copy of the Ebook Amazon Apple Google Kobo Description Details This Place Is Who We Are profiles Indigenous communities in central and northern coastal BC that are reconnecting to their lands and waters—and growing and thriving through this reconnection. Indigenous peoples and cultures are integrally connected to the land. Well-being in every sense—physical, social, environmental, economic, spiritual and cultural—depends on that relationship, which is based on a fundamental concept: when the land is well, so are the people. With increasing strength, Indigenous peoples in this vast region of BC—which spans the homelands of more than two dozen First Nations and one of the largest remaining coastal temperate rainforests in the world—are restoring what has been lost through environmental depredation and healing what has been devastated by colonization. This volume is a collection of ten of these inspiring stories. X̱aayda voices explain how their Rediscovery camps are healing and empowering their youth; Dzawada̱’enuxw Hereditary Chief Maxwiyalidizi K’odi Nelson shares the story of building a healing centre and ecolodge; Wei Wai Kum Chief Christopher Roberts describes the challenges and opportunities for an urban First Nation looking to prosper while protecting the environment and ancient Ligʷiłdaxʷ history and living cultural values; and many more Indigenous leaders share their own experiences of growth, strength and reconnection. Thoughtful and inspiring, This Place Is Who We Are illustrates what can be accomplished when conservation and stewardship are inextricably intertwined with the prosperity and well-being of communities. Prize(s): Winner Jeanne Clarke Award (2024), Short-listed Roderick Haig-Brown Regional Book Prize (2024), Runner-up BC Historical Writing Award (2023) “Katherine Palmer Gordon, a consummate listener, weaves a powerful tapestry of ten First Nations people, deeply grounded in land, memory and story. Their lives honour the inextinguishable inter-connectedness of humans and nature, in righteous defiance of colonization. These are stories that point to an optimistic future based on the teachings of Ancestors and Elders with a view to making the world better for children, grandchildren and children yet to come. To do this, human wellbeing and land protection must be inseparable. This book is an encounter with wonderful people doing wonderful things. This Place is Who We Are is an invitation to hope for a better society, a better world, featuring ten people creating it. I thank the contributors and Katherine Palmer Gordon for engaging in a visionary conversation.” –Shelagh Rogers, O.C. Host/Producer of The Next Chapter , CBC Radio One, Honorary Witness, Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada “A beautiful collection of stories and lived experiences! Each with gentle and loving reminders of our sacred connections to each other, the land and water and all living beings. Individually, these stories are inspiring, hopeful and thought provoking. As a collection, majestically woven together by Katherine Palmer Gordon, they have the potential to change hearts and minds of readers, decision makers and future generations.” –Monique Gray Smith “An astute facilitator of Indigenous governmental relationships and reconciliation, Katherine Palmer Gordon is also an award-winning writer, and a very good listener who earns trust. These deeply personal accounts of Indigenous cultural rediscovery, empowerment—and healing in a post-colonial world—are truly inspiring. Steeped in ancient connections with the land, the shared wisdom and vision of elders, youth and community leaders offer timely lessons for a healthier, more respectful relationship between people, wildlife and our planet. This is good medicine for all.” –Mark Forsythe, Co-author of The Trail of 1858: British Columbia's Gold Rush Past and former CBC Radio host Harbour Publishing ISBN: 9781990776137 Paperback / softback 8 in x 10 in - 256 pp Publication Date: 06/05/2023 BISAC Subject(s): NAT011000-NATURE / Environmental Conservation & Protection,SOC062000-SOCIAL SCIENCE / Indigenous Studies,BUS094000-BUSINESS & ECONOMICS / Green Business Description This Place Is Who We Are profiles Indigenous communities in central and northern coastal BC that are reconnecting to their lands and waters—and growing and thriving through this reconnection. These major changes are coming to downtown West Palm Beach's CityPlace News Sports Restaurants Real Estate Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals WEST PALM BEACH These major changes are coming to downtown West Palm Beach's CityPlace Alexandra Clough Palm Beach Post Stephen Ross, chairman of Related Ross, said he is working to transform West Palm Beach into a model city that will be in "the most important county in the United States." To get there, Ross will continue to upgrade downtown's CityPlace, a massive mixed-use project that changed downtown when it opened in October 1999. New developments were shared by officials after March 12 groundbreaking of the company's newest planned office towers, 10 and 15 CityPlace, at Rosemary Avenue and Hibiscus Street. Ross, also owner of the Miami Dolphins , said: "We are doing everything we can to bring all the amenities and activities needed to sustain the growth we're looking at today." Some of those include: ∎ Related Ross development company is hoping to strike a deal with Publix to build a new West Palm Beach grocery store that would be nearly double the size of an existing store at CityPlace . ∎ More restaurants and furniture stores will take space at CityPlace. ∎ The opening of the Eataly Italian Market in the historic Harriet Himmel Theater this year. 15 CityPlace and 10 CityPlace towers More: The Square complex in West Palm Beach reverts to its former, beloved name: CityPlace The 15 CityPlace tower, and a companion tower next door dubbed 10 CityPlace, will add 1 million square feet of office space to the downtown when completed in 2027. Some 4,700 employees could work in the towers when they are fully occupied, said Ken Himmel, president of Related Ross. The 25-story, 500,000-square-foot 15 CityPlace tower is 60% pre-leased to office tenants, officials said. More: West Palm's new office tower One Flagler opens as Related Ross works on other projects Among the building's many perks is a 6,000-square-foot rooftop amenity deck, said the tower's architect, Bernardo Fort Brescia, co-founder of Arquitectonica. These tenants included the previously announced Cleveland Clinic Florida medical offices, which will total 120,000 square feet. They also include two newly revealed tenants: Shutts & Bowen, Related Ross' law firm and a current tenant of another office building owned by Ross; and Inclenberg Investments, a private real estate investment firm with an office in Palm Beach. The size of these office leases was not disclosed. Is a larger Publix coming to CityPlace? As for a larger Publix, Himmel said talks with the Lakeland-based grocery chain still are underway, and Related Ross needs to buy one additional piece of property for a new, larger store. The new store would be built at the northwest corner of Banyan Boulevard and Rosemary Avenue, a few blocks north of the current Publix store at Fern Street and Rosemary Avenue. Talks have been ongoing with Publix for five years, Himmel acknowledged, but the grocery chain previously backed away from opening a larger store at CityPlace. However, in the past couple of years, with the surge in the city's population and upgrades being made to the CityPlace district, a bigger store once again is a possibility, he said. Food hall Eataly could draw more than 1 million visitors The $45 million Eataly market will feature 30,000 square of interior space, plus outside seating. The market is being built in the historic Harriet Himmel Theater. Mayor Keith James, who attended the groundbreaking, said Eataly will attract further interest in the city. "You want something that will bring people from all over the county, maybe all over the region, and I think Eataly will be a great draw," James said. Himmel said Eataly also is a draw for restaurants hoping to get spillover business from the foot traffic and customers who visit the food hall. Other new restaurants coming to CityPlace In fact, more than half a dozen restaurants are slated to be built at CityPlace in the next few years, Himmel said. Among them is Moxie's, a Canada-based chain that does $17 million a year in revenue at each of its two other locations in South Florida. In addition, a restaurant will be built inside the cottage that once housed the former Hibiscus House Bed & Breakfast, a property that Related Ross now owns. Home furnishing stores to open at CityPlace Home furnishings are an important element, too, in the CityPlace retail lineup. Perigold, part of the Wayfair furniture company, will open at the end of the year, and Crate & Barrel will open at CityPlace, too, joining West Elm at the center. As for the existing RH store on Okeechobee Boulevard, just south of CityPlace, that store does more than $80 million in volume, the third busiest store in the company's chain, Himmel said. CityPlace Real Estate and Property Management Indy | From $60 a Month | Call Today Skip to content Skip to content About Us FAQs Service Areas Indianapolis Property Management Fountain Square Property Management Carmel Property Management Noblesville Property Management Beech Grove Property Management Property Management Property Management Owner Portal Real Estate Available Rentals Available Rentals Self Show Rentals Renters Renters Tenant Portal Pay Rent Online Maintenance Request Tenant Application About Us FAQs Service Areas Indianapolis Property Management Fountain Square Property Management Carmel Property Management Noblesville Property Management Beech Grove Property Management Property Management Property Management Owner Portal Real Estate Available Rentals Available Rentals Self Show Rentals Renters Renters Tenant Portal Pay Rent Online Maintenance Request Tenant Application CALL TODAY CALL TODAY Our Vision To Be The Most Trusted Property Management Expert in Indianapolis We're dedicated. CityPlace is committed to being the most trusted all-in-one property management expert in Indianapolis. We've been in business since 2015, and we're dedicated to revolutionizing property management in Central Indiana. We promise to ensure your ownership journey is simplified and successful. We're your neighbors. Our ownership team has been doing this for over thirty years combined, right here in Indianapolis. Our office on Shelby Street is easy to find and getting in touch with us is a breeze. Meet our Owners Keith Farabee Owner Keith is a graduate of Indiana University and began his career as a Financial Advisor. He transitioned from managing investment portfolios and entered the Real Estate field in 2009 to start working with real estate investors. He has helped his clients acquire rental properties as well as manage their homes. Keith is also an investor in Real Estate himself so he understands the issues that come along with Real Estate Investing. Contact Amanda Farabee Owner Amanda is the office manager at CityPlace. She handles onboarding, contracts, and the day-to-day activities of the company. She has been in real estate since 2014. Before that, she worked in the health insurance field for 15+ years which gave her the skills to be organized and detail oriented, two very important tools when it comes to managing hundreds of rental properties. Outside of work, she enjoys traveling, wineries, and camping in a RV with her husband and dog Quinn. Contact Josh Compton Owner With 15 years of experience as a real estate professional and licensed General Contractor, Josh has overseen the completion of nearly 1,000 projects. Based in Central Indiana with a family of four, Josh is deeply rooted in his community. Contact BUYING OR SELLING? We have an expert team of real estate brokers who are well-versed in all transactions, including investments! What We're REPORTING CITY HALL Climate Criminal Justice Economy ERIC ADAMS HOUSING IMMIGRATION Labor NYPD Transit Follow Us Twitter Bluesky Facebook Instagram RSS Feed About Us Ways to Give merch store About Us Contact US Team Awards REPUBLISH Skip to content Menu THE CITY - NYC News Reporting to New Yorkers Donate Open Search Search for: Search Donate Menu Credit: Ben Fractenberg/THE CITY Home » Team THE CITY serves the people of New York through independent journalism that holds the powerful to account, deepens democratic participation and helps make sense of the greatest city in the world. More About Us Impact and Awards Team Board Ethics & Community Guidelines Funders Ways to Give Press Room Republishing Guidelines Jobs Privacy & Terms Contact Us On This Page Leadership Staff Credits On this page Leadership Staff Credits Leadership Nic Dawes Executive Director Nic is THE CITY’s executive director, responsible for growing the organization’s reach, impact and strategy as well for revenue and business operations. email Richard Kim Editor-in-Chief Richard is the editor in chief of The CITY, where he sets the editorial vision of the newsroom and oversees day-to-day operations. email Beth Eisenstaedt Chief Development Officer Beth is THE CITY’s chief development officer, where she oversees all fundraising strategy and manages donor relationships and communications, helping to strengthen our newsroom and community. email Jessica Lysons Director of Finance and Administration Jessica is THE CITY’s director of finance and administration, where she works with leadership to strengthen overall organizational capacity and impact. email Staff Rosalind Adams Senior Reporter Rosalind  is an investigative reporter for THE CITY, where she reports on cannabis legalization. More by Rosalind Adams email Claudia Irizarry Aponte Senior Reporter Claudia is a senior reporter covering labor and work for THE CITY. More by Claudia Irizarry Aponte email Reuven Blau Senior Reporter Reuven is a reporter for THE CITY, with a special focus on criminal justice and the city’s prison system. More by Reuven Blau email Haidee Chu Reporter Haidee Chu is a Queens-based reporter for THE CITY. She writes human-interest features and combines data analysis with shoe-leather reporting to document the way public policies and programs impact everyday New Yorkers. More by Haidee Chu email Jonathan Custodio Reporter Jonathan is THE CITY’s Bronx reporter, where he covers the latest news out of the city’s northernmost borough. More by Jonathan Custodio email Greg David Contributor Greg David is a contributor and Ravitch fiscal and economics reporter at THE CITY. He spent 35 years at Crain’s New York Business as editor, editorial director and a columnist. He is also the director of the business and economics reporting program at the Craig Newmark Graduate School of Journalism at CUNY as well as the Ravitch Fiscal Reporting Program. More by Greg David email Ben Fractenberg Visual Producer Ben is a visual producer for THE CITY, where he brings THE CITY’s stories to life through visual journalism and powerful photo essays. More by Ben Fractenberg email Brittney George Executive Assistant Brittney is an executive assistant with THE CITY, where she supports the leadership team, board of directors, and operations. email Hasani Gittens Deputy Editor Hasani Gittens is a founding deputy editor of THE CITY, where he has overseen coverage of beats ranging from transit to incarceration, and juvenile justice to public service journalism. More by Hasani Gittens email Yoav Gonen Senior Reporter Yoav is a senior reporter for THE CITY, where he covers NYC government, politics and the police department. More by Yoav Gonen email Martin Gottlieb Senior Editor, Investigations Martin Gottlieb is THE CITY’s senior editor for investigations. email Gwynne Hogan Senior Reporter Gwynne Hogan is a senior reporter covering immigration, homelessness, and many things in between. Her coverage of the migrant crisis earned her the Newswomen’s Club of New York’s Journalist of the Year award in 2023. Her reporting on the COVID-19 pandemic forced the New York City officials to admit they were undercounting the dead, and earned her a 2021 Gracie award. Send her tips at ghogan@thecity.nyc. More by Gwynne Hogan email Katie Honan Senior Reporter Katie is a reporter for THE CITY and co-host of FAQ NYC podcast. More by Katie Honan email Alyssa Katz Executive Editor Alyssa is executive editor with THE CITY, where she leads high-impact accountability reporting on New York City, including investigations, data projects, and  economic coverage. More by Alyssa Katz email Samantha Maldonado Senior Reporter Samantha is a senior reporter for THE CITY, where she covers climate, resiliency, housing and development. More by Samantha Maldonado email Jose Martinez Senior Reporter Jose is THE CITY’s transportation reporter, where he covers the latest developments and policies impacting traffic and transit in the city. More by Jose Martinez email Sam Rabiyah Contributing Editor, Data and News Apps Sam is a contributing editor to THE CITY working on data and news applications. He previously served as a news applications developer and reporter. More by Sam Rabiyah Diana Riojas Audience Manager, Engagement and Distribution Diana is THE CITY’s audience manager, where she oversees the newsroom’s social media platforms, engagement work and distribution strategy. email Morgan Sapp Development Manager Morgan is THE CITY’s Development Manager, where she supports fundraising initiatives and donor engagement. email Sujin Shin Product Developer Sujin is THE CITY’s product developer. More by Sujin Shin email Harry Siegel Senior Editor Harry Siegel is THE CITY’s senior editor, where he oversees THE CITY’s borough coverage. He’s also the creator and co-host of its FAQ NYC podcast, as well as a columnist at the New York Daily News. More by Harry Siegel email Greg B. Smith Senior Investigative Reporter Greg is an award-winning investigative reporter at THE CITY with a special focus on corruption and the city’s public housing system. More by Greg B. Smith email Rachel Holliday Smith Managing Editor Rachel is managing editor at THE CITY leading explanatory and service journalism in the newsroom. More by Rachel Holliday Smith email Colophon & Credits THE CITY is reported, written, edited, designed, photographed, programmed, recorded, promoted, fundraised-for and produced in New York City. Our thanks for the makers who created the following, wherever they work: Display typeface Sharp Grotesk by Sharp Type. Hamburger Menu icon by Selot Lo / The Noun Project How to New York pigeon icon by Kevin / The Noun Project Speech Balloon icon by iconbysonny / The Noun Project Nellie the Pigeon logo by Anje Jager . THE CITY is an independent nonprofit newsroom dedicated to serving the people of New York. Questions? info@thecity.nyc THE CITY is published by City Report, Inc.
